story: The Wemyss Hotel on Links Road, owned by Heinekenrsquos Star Pubs and Bars, is to reopen later this summer with a new name, The Seaglass Inn, and new operators, mother-and-daughter team Christine OrsquoBrien and Sarah Couch.Christine grew up in Prestonpans and runs The New Plough Inn, with her father Tam OrsquoBrien, in Tranent.She said: ldquoI love this part of the world so itrsquos fantastic to have a second pub here.ldquoHaving spoken to friends in Port Seton, they are crying out for a place they can eat out in the village and one that welcomes families.ldquoWe want to bring a taste of Edinburgh to the village, so that people can enjoy good food and drink in lovely surroundings on their doorstep without the need to travel.ldquoWersquore aiming to cater for the whole community and for all occasions, whether itrsquos a morning coffee, a pub lunch, a celebration dinner or evening drinks.ldquoIrsquove run hospitality businesses with my parents and itrsquos exciting to carry on the family tradition and start a new venture with my daughter. Working with Sarah will also enable me to be front of house at both The New Plough and The Seaglass.The exterior and interior of the building is now beingrenovated, with new signage, lighting and outside planting, and the pubrsquos garden is gettinga makeover with new furniture, decking and festoon lighting.There will also be a change in menu, with fresh and locally sourced food making its way into the newly installed kitchen.Brian Davidson, Star Pubs and Bars operations director for Scotland, said: ldquoWith so many new homes being built on the A corridor, therersquos a shortage of great pubs that serve food.ldquoWersquore delighted to be joining forces with Christine and Sarah to broaden the appeal of The Wemyss Hotel.ldquoWersquoll be working flat out to get The Seaglass open so that people can use the garden over the summer.

title: treasurer-embezzled-thousands-of-pounds-from-community-charity
story: Brian Smith was in charge of the finances at Cockenzie House and Gardens for less than a year when he began siphoning off pound, from the charityrsquos bank account.Smith, , used the stolen cash to pay for his day-to-day living expenses.Smithrsquos callous scam went unnoticed for about six months until it began to unravel and he went into his local police station and confessed all in April last year.The Cockenzie-based charity has described the theft as ldquoa devastating blow and said the non-profit organisation was just days from closing down due to Smithrsquos deceit.He has now been ordered to pay the massive sum back to the charity through a compensation order and been placed on supervision for eight months following an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court last week.Smith, of Old Course Gate, Musselburgh, was also ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community.The court was told that Smithrsquos home has been repossessed due to the mortgage not being paid and he will be in a position to pay all the cash back to the charity within six months.Sherf Donald Corke told Smith he had ldquocynically and greedily drained the charityrsquos bank account and had left ldquofinancial chaos in his wake.The sherf added: ldquoYou have pled guilty at the first opportunity to embezzling pound, from the charity. You were a voluntary treasurer at that time and it was a gross breach of trust.ldquoYou cynically and greedily drained the charityrsquos money and spent it on your own household expenses.Smith had previously pleaded guilty to the embezzlement charge when defending solicitor Mary Moultrie revealed her client had gone to the police and handed himself in.Smith, a former used car salesman, became involved with the charity in  after his we had rented an art studio within Cockenzie House.The father-of-two soon became treasurer after helping to overhaul the charityrsquos IT system but within months he was pilfering cash from its bank account.It is believed that Smith racked up about pound, in debt in the charityrsquos name after he failed to pay rent and utility bills over the period he acted as treasurer.A spokesperson for the charity said: ldquoThis has been a very dficult and challenging time for Cockenzie House and Gardens as we have lost half of our annual turnover through this embezzlement.Despite this devastating blow, the trustees are proud to say we have managed to make a good recovery and our focus now is to continue to build a sustainable future for the charity.Smith pleaded guilty to embezzling pound, while treasurer of Cockenzie House and Gardens between May , , and April  last year.

title: children-traumatised-after-familys-car-is-torched-in-musselburgh
story: Musselburgh High Street trader Neil Wilson has been left reeling after finding his black Volkswagen Sharan people carrier completely burnt out and his wersquos red Honda Jazz doused in turpentine as the town prepared to welcome runners for this yearrsquos Edinburgh Marathon.The Town Champion at Musselburghrsquos  Riding of the Marches and a former Honest Lad, Mr Wilson parked the two vehicles in a field belonging to his neighbours, which is earmarked for about  new houses, at the back of his Ravensheugh Road home.The private route which leads to his house is blocked off for the annual run.ldquoIrsquove done that for the past six years when the marathon is on, said Mr Wilson who owns a greengrocerrsquos shop in the town and is a former president of the Rotary Club of Musselburgh and a former president of the Honest Tounrsquos Association.He said: ldquoI usually park the cars in a private yard at my house but the private road which leads to my house is blocked off for the marathon, so I can access the field opposite Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre on Haddington Road.The family had been visiting relatives on the Saturday evening before the marathon on the Sunday and ed at about .pm and parked their cars in the field out of public view.They went to bed and, in the morning, Mr Wilsonrsquos we Nicci and six-year-old daughter Imogen, who plays football for the Musselburgh Windsor under-nine team, went to the cars at about .am as they were due to travel to Bathgate for a game with a .am kick-off.Mr Wilson said: ldquoAs my we walked along, she felt something was not right and when she got closer she could smell it ndash the car was completely and utterly burnt out.ldquoIt was traumatic for my daughter who did not want to go near it.ldquoIt was still burning hot, although there were no flames.The police were contacted and Mr Wilson went to see what had happened.ldquoThe Volkswagen Sharan was decimated, he said.ldquoThere was nothing left, only shells of things in the back of the car. The glass had melted because it was so hot.ldquoThe field was not dry because of heavy rain or it could quite easily have set fire to the field.Mr Wilson said that most of their belongings had been taken out of the people carrier but two pairs of his trainers and sports equipment were destroyed.He added: ldquoThe window of my wersquos car had been broken and accelerant, turpentine I think, was poured into it and there was a box of matches inside.He said it was possibly because of the rain the car had not caught alight.His daughterrsquos schoolbag, which was in the back of his wersquos car, was ruined by the turpentine and her tap dancing clothes had also been doused in the liquid.Mr Wilson said: ldquoAlthough the window has been repaired, the smell is still quite overpowering and almost gives you a headache.ldquoWe tried our best to get the turpentine out but it is dficult to get rid of the smell by washing and vacuuming.ldquoMy children have taken it quite badly. My daughter was scared someone would come back and do it to my wersquos car and my nine-year-old son Angus has had dficulty getting a full nightrsquos sleep.ldquoIt is dficult to explain why people would do such a thing to someone rsquos property. It is scary for the children.Mr Wilson said the family were out of pocket as the insurance company wouldnrsquot cover the cost of the excess plus their personal belongings.He believed it was a random act of fireraising, adding: ldquoSomeone has been out to set something alight or has gone home to get an accelerant. It is not a silly act after the pub. I hope they feel guilty about what they have done.A police spokesperson said: ldquoWe were called to Ravensheugh Road around .am on Sunday, May , following reports two cars had been vandalised. Enquiries into this incident are continuing.

title: lorry-driver-told-to-get-out-and-take-a-kicking-from-irate-motorist
story: Alexander McLeod drove on the wrong side of the road and pulled up in front of the large truck before getting out of his car and demanding driver Colin Holmes fight with him.McLeod shouted, ldquoYou f***ing a***hole at the man. He then yelled: ldquoGet out, Irsquom going to give you a kicking during the incident at Willowbrae Road, Edinburgh.McLeod, of Suthren Yett, claimed that the truck driver had collided with his car and driven away moments before he decided to chase after the lorry.The -year-old building firm owner appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where he admitted two charges committed during the road rage incident.Solicitor Colm Dempsey told the court that his client had four children and employed two full-time workers at his building firm.Mr Dempsey said that McLeod had become irate after a piece of plant machinery on the back of the truck had struck McLeodrsquos car as they both negotiated road works at Willowbrae.He said McLeod thought the driver had failed to notice the collision and then ldquomade the stupid decision to stop in front of the vehicle.Mr Dempsey said that the damage to his clientrsquos car had been about pound, and admitted: ldquoHe is too old to be behaving like this.The solicitor pleaded with Sherf John Cook not to ban McLeod, who already had six penalty points on his licence, from driving as this would affect his livelihood.Sherf Cook agreed and sentenced McLeod to a pound, fine and placed five penalty points on his licence.McLeod admitted driving on the opposite carriageway, bringing a vehicle to a halt and causing it to perform an emergency stop at Willowbrae Road, Edinburgh, on October  last year. He also pleaded guilty to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting, swearing and challenging Colin Holmes to fight during the same incident.

title: preview-musselburgh-gala-2019
story: Organised by Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council, the fun-packed event is adored by youngsters in the Honest Toun.From noon until pm, there is a range of activities on offer including shows, quad bikes, face painting and dance displays.Edinburgh magician Alexander the Great will enthral gala visitors with his magic and circus skills show and Dinky Donuts will be present to keep those hunger pangs at bay.East Coast FM lead the fun and games as compegraveres.Also present will be Musselburghrsquos Army Cadets, Air Cadets and Sea Cadets, with musical entertainment provided by the Penicuik and Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band.Representatives from Musselburgh Area Partnership will also be on hand to discuss its work with the local community.The Brunton Bistro serves tea, coffee, sandwiches and pies in a marquee.For those who prefer a snack as they enjoy the many activities, Sizzlers are selling food such as burgers, bacon rolls and chips. There is also a bar.The community council has been running the gala for the past  years in partnership with East Lothian Council.For pound entry, all the attractions ndash apart from the quad bikes, which cost an extra pound ndash are available at no extra cost.Also included in the ticket price is a goodie bag with chocolate, a carton of juice or water, and packet of crisps, as well as an ice cream from J  J Ices in Musselburgh.Irene Tait, community council chairwoman, said: ldquoThe gala is such a popular family event in the town.ldquoWe are hoping as many people as possible will come along this year to enjoy the iety of attractions which are on offer.ldquoWe are always delighted to see everyone having such fun.Tickets are available from The Brunton box office in Musselburgh.

title: pictures-galas-held-across-east-lothian
story: Gala days took place in East Linton, Longniddry and Musselburgh on Saturday, while Tranent Gala came to a close with the grand parade that evening.Here are a selection of photos from the events - lots more will appear in this weeks Courier, out on Thursday.

title: suggestion-of-banning-dogs-from-north-berwicks-east-beach
story: Concerns have been raised about unruly dogs on the townrsquos East Beach.The issue was discussed at the townrsquos community and police partnershipmeeting, where it was agreed to contact East Lothian Council about the possibility of signs being put in place banning dogs.Kathryn Smith, secretary of North Berwick Community Council, attended the meeting and told the Courier: ldquoWe discussed the issue and it was agreed we should write to the legal department of East Lothian Council to seewe could enforce a dog-free zone. It would probably be on the East Beach between April and October.The dog-free zone could be in place between certain times of the day, with a suggestion of am to pm.The community council secretary said the issue surrounded dogs being ldquonot under control and potentially jumping up on a child.It would not be the first area in the county to ban dogs, with the animals already barred from the Local Nature Reserve at Aberlady.Any move to ban dogs from North Berwickrsquos beach would require a public consultation.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council stressed that dog walkers had to keep control of the animal.She said: ldquoCountryside Rangers work closely with Scottish Natural Heritage in promoting the Scottish Outdoor Access Code which requires dog owners, in places where other people are around and in particular children, to keep their dog close at heel or on a short lead.

title: two-car-accident-on-the-a1-near-haddington
story: The incident, which took place at about .am this morning , took place on the westbound carriageway, near Haddington.A spokesman for Police Scotland said: "It appears the driver in a light blue car has been driving the wrong way between Haddington and Dunbar.""The driver of another vehicle has then swerved to avoid the vehicle and hit the central reservation but sustained no serious injuries."Enquiries are ongoing in a bid to trace the driver of the light blue car."Traffic Scotland had tweeted that the northbound westbound carriageway was closed but one lane has now re-opened.

title: gardening-scotland-success-for-east-lothian-groups-pallet-gardens
story: East Lothian plant-lovers were among the winners at Scotlandrsquos national gardening show at the Royal Highland showground at Ingliston.The one-metre-square pallet garden competition was set up  years ago to encourage voluntary groups and schools to participate.Entering for the first time, Tranentrsquos Blooming Belters won gold and first prize, highlighting how they have been reinvigorating their town centre with floral displays.The garden featured a replica of a mine pithead with more than  types of ferns, as it was these plants that formed the coal which was associated with the town for so long.By contrast, North Berwick in Bloom has been in every show for the past  years.This year, its lsquoNow the War is Overrsquo pallet demonstrated how wild flowers, including the well-known red poppies, had colonised the First World War battlefields by the spring of .The garden also acknowledged the contribution of horses, dogs and carrier pigeon to the British forces.Miss Youngsonrsquos PC class at North Berwickrsquos Law Primary School took a gold with a garden linking flowers to music, with Burnsrsquo red, red rose the centrepiece.Rosmary Oberlander, retired from North Berwick in Bloom, gave the children a helping hand.She said: ldquoAll the children in the class were involved ndash initially we talked through ideas and then they drew up their designs.ldquoEveryone decorated some cut-out musical notes and then helped either to decorate the keyboard poles or plant up some of the musical instruments which were donated to us.Law Primaryrsquos nursery entered for the first time with a seaside theme which achieved silver gilt.Meanwhile, three pupils from Knox Academy also attended the Royal Horticultural Society Gardening Scotland show.The pupils planned, designed and created a sensory garden from scratch.Karen Fraser, from the Haddington secondary school, said: ldquoThe young people used the theme of a sensory garden with particular emphasis on each of the five senses.ldquoAfter several hoursrsquo work, we submitted our garden and awaited judging from the RHS judges and the general public.ldquoThis was our first year entering and we were genuinely not expecting to be placed, but we had great fun creating our garden.ldquoWe learned that we had been placed third, gaining a bronze statuette.

title: preview-dunbar-civic-week-2019
story: Dunbar Civic Week was established in  to mark the th anniversary of the Royal Charter, granted by King David II, which created the Burgh of Dunbar.The staple of the Dunbar social calendar starts on Saturday and runs until next Sunday .The popular celebration begins with the community parade, which meets at Dunbar Leisure Pool at .am.The parade then leaves at noon and makes its way to the townrsquos Bleachingfield Centre, where the crowning takes place at about .pm.Teagan Daley will be crowned this yearrsquos Civic Queen by former Queen Annie-Rose Dickson.The  Royal Court are: Queenrsquos Consort ndash Kai Lavery Queenrsquos Attendants ndash Isla McLaughlin and Abby Cowan Pageboys ndash Kaelen McLaren and Lukas Dulieba Flowergirls ndash Eden Francis and Anya MacIver.A fun day, featuring face-painters, balloon modellers and a range of sporting activities, then takes place at Bleachingfield Park.Also taking place on Saturday is a football festival at Hallhill, am-pm Biking the Bounds from the Bleachingfield Centre at .am a Victorian Portrait Studio at McArthurrsquos Stores, Victoria Street, noon-pm The Three Craws an the mysterious licht at Sunny Dunbar at The Battery at .pm and Dunbar Archery Club come and try session at Dunbar Parish Church Hall from pm.On Sunday, a family fun day is held at Dunbar Cement Plant from am, while there is a Kwik Cricket Festival at Winterfield Park between am and pm. Also taking place on the day is an open afternoon at Dunbar Leboat Station from pm, while there is Gospel music at Dunbar Day Centre at pm.Dunbar Community Councilrsquos community awards take place on Monday, from pm at the Town House, while Dunbar Music School holds a series of short --minute concerts by Dunbar Music School CIC at St Annersquos Church at .pm . The day also brings Beyond Monopoly: st Century Boardgaming for Beginners at Belhaven Church Stables, -pm.On Tuesday, there is a chance to make your own Dunbar emoji, at the Seams Sew shop on High Street at .pm, as well as a CoastWord Haverings Special for Dunbar Civic Week at pm at the Station Yard Micropub.Then on Wednesday, the royal court tree planting is held at .am at the Ridge Backlands, as well as a five-a-side football tournament at Hallhill, .pm registration for pm start.Also on Wednesday there are Bookbug sessions at the Bleachingfield Library at am and am an open day at Dunbar Day Centre, am-pm and a beetle drive with st Belhaven Guides at Belhaven Church Hall from .pm.Events continue throughout the week until he curtain comes down on the festival next Sunday with the thanksgiving service at Dunbar Battery at .pm.For a full list of events, see dunbarcivicweek.org.uk

title: suspicious-object-sparks-coastguard-callout-after-it-washes-up
story: The volunteer crews from Dunbar and North Berwick were called to the picturesque bay at about am today .A spokesman for North Berwickrsquos coastguard team said: ldquoA member of the public called the coastguard as they were unsure as to what the object was and that it may pose a risk.ldquoOn scene the team were able to confirm this was in fact an old mooring which had been washed ashore and posed no risk.ldquoThe informant did the right thing by calling to advise the coastguard.Due to its weight, the old mooring is still sitting on the beach.The coastguard spokesman added: ldquoIf you see someone in dficulty or something you are concerned about on the shoreline, beaches, clfs, mud or water, call  immediately and ask for the coastguard.

title: section-of-a1-to-close-overnight-for-six-nights-for-roadworks
story: The westboundcarriageway of the A between Abbotsview Junction and Oaktree Junction, both at Haddington, will shut each night between next Tuesdayand Monday, July .The closure will be in force between pm and am each night as part of a pound, road maintenance scheme.Meanwhile, from next Wednesday , between am and pm, the westbound carriageway between the two junctions will be one lane only to allow the surfacing material to cool.A signed ersion route will be in place during the overnight closures.Westbound traffic will be instructed to exit via the Abbotsview off-slip road and, at the roundabout, traffic will take the second exit onto the A.Traffic will be directed to proceed on this route towards the roundabout at Oaktree Junction, where it will take the third exit to rejoin the A westbound via the on-slip road.Amey, which is responsible for the A, said the work would benefit more than , vehicles using this section of the A each day by improving the condition of the carriageway and reducing the need for more extensive maintenance in the future.The work has been planned in consultation with Transport Scotland, Traffic Scotland, emergency services, and East Lothian Council.

title: plans-lodged-for-new-a1-sliproad-at-queen-margaret-university
story: The changes to the road are being carried out to allow major development surrounding Queen Margaret Universityat Musselburgh to go ahead.Currently the only way to get to the university from the A is from the eastbound carriageway, heading from Edinburgh into East Lothian.The new slip roadswill create an access and exit route on the westbound carriageway, with a new underpass built beneath the main road and new roundabout built to the west of it.Drawings of the proposals have been lodged by the council with itsown planning department.The application states that the proposals will ldquocomplete a junction commenced in  through planning approval that was to access land used for agriculture which could be developed affording opportunities for employment land.More than  hectaresof land around the university, straddling the A, has been given the go-ahead for a major mixed use development.As well as , new homes, there are proposals for an innovation hub connected to the universityitself, business and commercial spaces, a primary school and public spaces.It is anticipated that the innovation hub could create up to , new jobs in the area and it has secured funding from the Edinburgh and South East of Scotland City Deal.However, it has been accepted that the new development will need upgrades to the access points from the A, leading to the plans being lodged.The cost and timescale of the new project is unclear. The council said: ldquoUntil due planning process is complete, we cannot advise on costs and timescales.Barry Turner, of Musselburgh Conservation Society, said: ldquoThis proposal is an essential development of this junction, enabling direct access to QMU and the proposed business park from the east.ldquoIt also opens up the area to the south of the A for development, though the conservation society would prefer to see this area left as open fields.

title: youngsters-dress-up-as-campie-primary-school-celebrates-centenary
story: Two days of celebrations were enjoyed, including the opportunity for people from the community to tour the school, view an exhibition of photos and memorabilia, and share their Campie memories.Ahead of the celebrations, children explored the schoolrsquos past, present and future in their learning, with the number  featuring in work around science, technology, engineering and maths.The festivities also featured a party in the playground, while teachers and children were able to dress up in costume from any decade in the last century.A school spokesperson said: ldquoWe had a wonderful celebration.ldquoThe school looked wonderful and everyone who came thoroughly enjoyed looking at old photos, sharing memories and meeting up with old friends and colleagues.ldquoMany of our children and staff dressed up on the Friday and there was such a happy feeling in the school. Thanks to everyone who donated photos and memorabilia, and who contributed in any way to our th birthday.Ward councillor Andy Forrest said: ldquoI would like to congratulate Campie on its th birthday. This is a fantastic achievement and it is a credit to the community, the level of support that has been given to the school.ldquoI would also like to thank staff past and present for the work put in by them to ensure there is a welcoming, friendly learning facility.The school opened on May , , with  pupils under the stewardship of headteacher Thomas Brown. Today, the school of  pupils is led by Pauline McKay and her team.The building at Stoneyhill Farm Road has been extended over the years, most recently in , to accommodate the growing school community.

title: car-club-withdraws-from-haddington-and-north-berwick
story: Co-wheels, the UKrsquos biggest car club, has withdrawn from the two towns from Saturday due to low usage levels.Members had been able to hire a Toyota Yaris based at Haddingtonrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre, a Toyota Aygo at North Berwickrsquos Glebe Car Park and a Renault Zoe EV at North Berwickrsquos Imperial Car Park.Tony Archer, Scottish location manager at Co-wheels, said: ldquoWe have decided to re-locate the Co-wheels cars in Haddington and North Berwick to alternative Scottish locations due to a greater demand of the car club where in the country. This will take effect from June . Registered members who have utilised the Haddington and North Berwick cars have been notied and we hope they will continue to use the Co-wheels car club service in other locations in the future.Co-wheels ndash which has been operating in East Lothian for more than six years ndash also has a Toyota Yaris hybrid based at Dunbar Railway Station and a Toyota Aygo X-Play Nav at the townrsquos Bleachingfield Centre, as well as a Toyota Yaris Hybrid at Bridge Street in Musselburgh and a Toyota Aygo X-Play Nav located on the townrsquos High Street.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, said: ldquoI am disappointed that Co-wheels has not managed to make a success of this very interesting venture. I understand there are other car clubs starting to look at setting up in East Lothian and will be interested to how this develops.His view was echoed by Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillor Tom Trotter, who was surprised by the news.He said: ldquoThat is sad. I had not heard anything in the build up to that it has come right out of the blue. I donrsquot know how much they were getting used but it is a service for people.Co-wheels is a pay-as-you-go car hire scheme where members can book cars online and use a smartcard to access them ndash no need for keys. At the end of the booking, members, who only pay for the hire time and distance they drive,the car to a dedicated parking bay.

title: mary-poppins-nursery-in-athelstaneford-to-close-this-summer
story: Mary Poppins Nursery in Athelstaneford has announced that its last day will be Friday, August , blaming the impact of the extension of funded hours by the Scottish Government for its impending closure.Owner Ruth Dewar said: ldquoThe decision was a very painful one.ldquoIn the past two years, it has been increasingly dficult to continue as a viable business. There are several factors influencing this, but the major factor which has tipped the balance is the extended funding hours and the negative impact this is having both financially on small businesses, like Mary Poppins, and to the quality of early learning and childcare.New Scottish Government policy instructs councils to increase their funded childcare hours from  to , by . This move also includes longer opening hours and a move from term time to year-round opening hours to attempt to make childcare more nationally accessible.Ms Dewar said: ldquoThe money received for funded places does not cover the costs of providing the quality of early learning and childcare which we want and are required to provide, especially with regards to staff costs.ldquoThe timescales and measures that the Scottish Government has put in place to educate a workforce to meet the increased requirements are insufficient, and there is a serious shortfall to meet the requirements of the extended funding.ldquoEast Lothian Council indicated it estimated it would require approximately  staff to facilitate the increase in funded hours in East Lothian. The majority of these posts are early learning and childcare practitioners.ldquoThe local authority advertises early learning practitioner posts at between pound. and pound. per hour. Private nurseries are unable to compete with these rates of pay due to the funding rates we are allocated.A group of parents and staff, including Ms Dewar, are visiting county MSP Iain Gray to discuss the problems, but Ms Dewar added that unless he can ldquowork a miracle and change the policy, then it is unlikely the decision to close the nursery will be reversed.When asked about the nursery, Mr Gray said: ldquoThe loss of any nursery provision is disappointing, particularly with the Governmentrsquos , funded hours policy set to be implemented next year.ldquoIn the case of the Mary Poppins Nursery, the owner has highlighted a number of factors that have contributed to their decision to close.ldquoI have written to East Lothian Council about some of these issues.ldquoHowever, there are also wider issues at play here. The nursery sector has been warning the Scottish Government that private nurseries are struggling in the run-up to the roll-out of its flagship , policy from August .ldquoMinisters must act quickly to address the sectorrsquos concerns and ensure that the capacity exists to deliver the funded hours next year.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoIt is, of course, concerning to hear of any nursery considering closure, and the obvious effects this might have on staff, parents and children.ldquoEast Lothian Council has provided assurance that they will support families to find alternative early learning and childcare places for children who had been expecting to use the Mary Poppins Nursery from this August.Ms Dewar added: ldquoI am distraught that circumstances have forced me to this decision and that such a wonderful place for children to experience their early years is to close.The decision was met with an outpouring of grief on social media.The nurseryrsquos recent th birthday was marked with a garden party.The nursery was founded by Sue Armstrong, affectionately still called lsquoMiss Suersquo, after she had written to Mary Poppins author P L Travers to askshe could use the name.Miss Sue said: ldquoI received many letters from P L Travers about the nursery.ldquoAt the beginning, she wanted to know what the nursery was going to be like. She had no objection to me using the name, she just wanted to find out more. I ended up meeting her as well.ldquoWe were hoping to get her to come and open the nursery  years ago, but her arthritis was bad. We stayed in touch, however. I would send her letters about how the nursery was getting on along with photos, and she would write back saying how she liked it, and ideas of what to do.ldquoShe said that the children should be encouraged to make up their own stories. lsquoChildren like doing that,rsquo she said.Miss Sue sold the nursery to Ms Dewar in  as she was ldquosick of all the paperwork.She said. ldquoWhen I heard it was to close down, well, itrsquos just all so sad really. Itrsquos such a terrible shame.ldquoIt is such a nice and happy place for the children, homely and warm. Itrsquos just awful that it canrsquot stay open.Miss Sue still attends events at the nursery, dressed as the iconic nanny Mary Poppins.She added: ldquoIn the film, Mary Poppins says that shersquoll stay until the winds change. Well, maybe this is the wind changing for Mary Poppins Nursery.Ward councillor Craig Hoy said: ldquoThe closure of the Mary Poppins Nursery is deeply regrettable but reflects the real pressures the independent sector is experiencing as a result of the SNPrsquos , hours policy."The Government faces huge problems to provide the free childcare it has promised. In many areas the level of nursery provision simply isnrsquot there and independent nurseries are already struggling financially with the planned expansion.

title: call-for-double-yellow-lines-at-busy-haddington-junction
story: Parked vehicles regularly line Hopetoun Drive and Rab Moran, from the townrsquos community council, called for double yellow lines to be put down near the streetrsquos junction with Hope Park.Mr Moran repeated his plea for action to be taken to solve the problem at the grouprsquos latest meeting.He said: ldquoI see somebody wrote into the Courier saying it was a tricky junction and I mentioned that as well.ldquoWhen you come round the corner it is like a brick wallsomebody is coming round to meet you.The community councillor stressed that Tustain Motors, which is based on the corner of Hopetoun Drive, was not to blame for the issue and it was simply a busy street.Mr Moranrsquos concerns were echoed by fellow community councillor Jack Worden, who agreed something needed to be done at the junction.

title: newhailes-house-added-to-new-outlander-locations-map
story: The th-century Palladian villa joins Beecraigs Country Park in West Lothian and Arniston House in Midlothian as three of eight new locations that feature in the fourth season of the time-travelling romantic television adventure series starring Caitriona Balfe and Sam Heughan.The Outlander map, created by the national tourism organisation, has been revamped to include more details, including postcodes and whether the on-screen locations feature parking, toilet facilities, admission fees and eateries.Newhailes, owned by the National Trust for Scotland, served as Governor Tyronrsquos home in North Carolina.Outlander locations are popular with visitors and the map now features  of the Scottish locations used in the hit Sony Pictures television show for fans to explore.Outlander follows the romantic adventures of English Second World War combat nurse Claire Randall, who travels back in time to th-century Scotland, where she meets and falls in love with Scottish Highlander Jamie Fraser.Find out more about the interactive online Outlander map at visitscotland outlander, while a printed version is available from select VisitScotland iCentres and featured locations.

title: re-opening-of-haddingtons-swimming-pool-is-delayed-a-month
story: The pool at the townrsquos Aubigny Sports Centre closed on April  as part of a nine-week refurbishment.However, enjoyleisure, which manages the sports centre, off the townrsquos Mill Wynd, confirmed that the pool would not re-open on Tuesday as planned.Instead, the opening date has been pushed back a month to July .Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, said: ldquoWhilst we are extremely disappointed with the delay, we remain extremely excited about the enhancements and improvements being provided for our customers.ldquoThese works will transform the swimming pool environment at Aubigny into a more modern and dynamic setting aimed at motivating and encouraging more people to get more active more often.ldquoAlthough the dry side facilities remain open at Aubigny, this extended closure of the swimming pool is not what anyone would wish.ldquoenjoy would welcome all our customers at any of our other swimming pools, which remain open.An email was sent out to enjoyleisure members which highlighted the problems.Tom Reid, head of infrastructure at East Lothian Council, echoed Mr Axonrsquos disappointment.He said: ldquoEveryone is looking forward to the completion of this renovation, which will transform the look of the pool for the benefit of the many people who use this much-loved facility.ldquoWe are disappointed that, due to a supply chain issue outwith our control, the date for the poolrsquos re-opening has been now been revised from the end of June with a new opening date of July .ldquoWe appreciate this will be frustrating for pool users who will be eagerly anticipating the poolrsquos re-opening and we are grateful for their patience and understanding.ldquoIrsquod like to assure everyone that we are working very closely with the contractor, subcontractor and enjoyleisure to complete the project within this revised timeframe.The pool hall dates back to the s, with the refurbishment plans including the complete replacement of custom-fit ceiling window  and a new roof covering.Both pools ndash the four-lane swimming pool and East Lothianrsquos only dedicated infant pool ndash were to be drained, with a new light ceiling covering replacing the wood cladding.A new energy-efficient lighting scheme is also to be fitted, which it is hoped will transform the look and feel of the facility.Existing wall tiles will be replaced with wall liner .The delay also means the pool will not be open ahead of the school summer holidays starting next Friday .While the pool and health suite are closed, the rest of the centre, including the gym, dance studio, sports hall and cafe, remain open.Ward councillor Craig Hoy said: ldquoThe delay to the reopening of the Aubigny Sports Centre swimming pool will clearly be disappointing for local residents hoping to use the facilities over the school holidays.ldquoI hope East Lothian Council continues to work closely with the contractors and enjoyleisure to ensure there are no further delays.ldquoThe renovation is very welcome, but as the Haddington population grows we still need to explore how to further enhance and expand our leisure and sporting facilities to ensure they remain on a level with those available where in the county and beyond.

title: oor-wullie-sculpture-arrives-in-east-lothian
story: A total of  sculptures capturing Scotlandrsquos favourite scamp are scattered across a nationwide arts trail for  weeks for charity.And the Scottish Seabird Centre in North Berwick has given one of them a home for the next three months.Seabird Spotting Wullie is sponsored by the Jess Mackie Memorial Fund and all donations made on its behalf go to Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity.The memorial fund, set up in memory of Gullane schoolgirl Jess, who died last year, raises money to support music therapy at the hospital.The sculpture was painted by artist Hannah Sanguinetti and features Oor Wullie pretending to be a sea clf, with seabirds sitting on him. Written on the back of his bucket are lists of the types of seabirds and marine le which can be spotted locally.The  Oor Wullie BIG Bucket Trail builds on the success of a similar trail in Dundee three years ago which raised nearly pound,.This time round, sculptures of the national treasure will be seen on the streets of Edinburgh, Glasgow, Aberdeen, Dundee, Inverness and surrounding communities.DC Thomson, which has published Oor Wullie cartoon strips and Christmas annuals featuring the character and his family since the late s, has teamed up with three childrenrsquos hospital charities to share funds raised by the latest trail: Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity, ARCHIE Foundation and Glasgow Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity.Primary schools have also been able to get involved, with a number receiving miniature sculptures of their own to decorate. The results are being put on display around Edinburgh at locations including the National Portrait Gallery, Museum of Childhood and Ocean Terminal.Charlotte Bray, fundraising manager at the Seabird Centre, said: ldquoAs a marine conservation charity the design was spot on and is a fun representation of the local wildle.ldquoThe Jess Mackie Memorial Fund have sponsored the sculpture, which gives it a special relevance for the local community.ldquoJess was a pupil at North Berwick High School and her family have done an incredible job of fundraising for ECHC in her memory.ldquoWe are very happy to be involved in such an exciting nationwide art trail.The trail has been organised in association with Wild in Art and supported by DC Thomson Media.The sculptures were officially unveiled on Monday and will remain until the end of August.A mobile app can be downloaded, with people encouraged to take on each or all of the trails recording each sculpture as they come across it. It also shows a map of each trail and where the sculptures can be found. See oorwullie

title: tims-tales-an-expedition-to-hailes-castle
story: IN DAYS gone by, when most people had to walk from place to place, our sense of distance was more acute.These days we speed by in a car or bus and donrsquot really appreciate just how far we are travelling. Five minutes in a car can cover a distance which would represent a fairly long walk.Itrsquos kind of a simple principle, I know, but one I sometimes forget, as I did a couple of weekends ago. We set off from an event at Amisfield Walled Garden for a walk. My idea was to walk along the River Tyne to Hailes Castle and thenndash by car a -minute round trip.We had some supplies in the form of fruit in my bag and a little water. It was a sunny and warm day and so we set off on our adventure.We began the walk at the old Abbey Bridge which spans the Tyne close to Amisfield. As you walk under its ancient ribbed arches of this late medieval bridge, you get a real sense of its age and the beauty of its construction.The path beyond follows the river and it is almost impossible now to imagine that a great abbey once stood here, with connections to the infant Mary Queen of Scots. A ruined old mill of later centuries still stands here. I reflected on the stories of this location: a courageous nun who defied a flood in the th century and a gruesome murder in the th century and just visible in the near distance the old graveyard, now ringed with trees and almost unrecognisable as a resting place for the dead.A labourer once thought he saw a ghost at the graveyard, but it proved to be something , and I had a wry smile at that tale of a drunken evening over  years ago. These are all tales I have already told here, but they entered my head as we wandered to the gate that led along the northern bank of the river.Hailes Castle is on the southern bank of the river and I knew that there was a bridge that would takes us over. So we set off to find the bridge.But it took us over four hours.It was a stunning walk, with wild flowers and trees decorating the riverbank almost all the way. A grey heron seemed to follow us perhaps he was warning us that the walk was longer than Irsquod anticipated.It is a walk decorated with history too, of course. A stone in the corner of the field by the first gate caught my eye. Deeply ingrained groove marks on it intrigued me. I was later told that it could be the marks of a plough, as the tips of the plough have scraped over the stone a ploughman unwittingly leaving evidence of his unrecorded toil.Halfway along the walk we arrived at the small hamlet of Sandyrsquos Mill. The cottages and mill itself have been beautully restored. The th-century mill still has its waterwheel, although itrsquos now embedded in silt. The mill ceased working  years ago and was transformed into a residential property, but with much of the old machinery inside still intact. It appears to be a very sympathetic and sensitive restoration.It was beyond Sandyrsquos Mill that the distance began to take its toll. The young kids were tired and desperately looking for the bridge. I spotted Traprain Law some distance away and realised that I had badly misjudged the distance and time it would take with wee ones. We had to sit and have a rest and story, with that grey heron listening, to gather the energy to continue.The kids didnrsquot complain much as we wandered along the still-beautul path, now desperately looking for the bridge. As we had rested wersquod phoned for friends to come and lsquorescuersquo us at Hailes Castle with chocolate and water, and we knew they were there waiting for us.Irsquove never been quite so pleased to see Hailes Castle. It loomed suddenly from across the river. I had never approached it from this direction and it certainly did its best to impress. The bridge was just a wee way further and we finally crossed it with a sense of relief.When we arrived at the castle, the kids devoured the chocolate and water, in a way that reminded me of a scene in the movie Ice Cold in Alex. Thank goodness for good friends.Wersquod made it and what a sense of adventure ndash and an achievement!I sat with the kids and told stories as my we went with the friends to retrieve our car. Hailes Castle drips with history but they wanted tales about giants.The day was a lesson for me: to think more carefully about distance when setting on a walk! I thoroughly recommend the path, especially on a lovely summerrsquos day. But itrsquos going to take half a dayyou have kids. So prepare for that!Unbelievably, the kids later wanted to go to a playpark. ldquoWhere do they get the energy  my we asked.ldquoFrom us! I replied!

title: hopes-of-seeing-railway-station-return-to-haddington
story: RAGESmet with Peter Brett Associates ndash a leading consultancy of engineers and planners ndash to outline the case for improved transports links to and from East Lothian.One of the more ambitious plans was to see theof a railway station to Haddington.Residents of the town have not been served by a railway station since , with the station closing to freight nearly  years later.However, RAGES feels there could still be a possibility of a station ing to the town ndash though the group acknowledged that work needed to be done.A spokesman for the group said: ldquoRAGES expressed its preference for re-opening of the Haddington branch, ideally to the previous terminus on Station Road.ldquoMinimal compulsory purchase relocation of existing industrial units would be required the biggest physical obstacle would be the reconstruction of the A overbridge which was unwisely built without preserving the railway alignment and loading gauge.ldquoA level crossing would be required at Gateside, failing which an alternative road access could be provided for the new houses on the north side of the line onto the A.There was also a suggestion of creating car parking and even a park and ride facility in the town to serve the new service, which would link the town with Edinburgh.The spokesman added: ldquoAs insufficient parking exists at Station Road , a park and ride station at Oak Tree would be essential, which could also serve the substantial Letham Mains and Gateside developments.ldquoJust east of where the A crosses the railway formation, there is a large rectangular piece of ground, occupied only by scrub, which would be suitable as a car park.ldquoAs only single track would suffice between Longniddry and Haddington, it would be possible to retain a footpath cycleway as the line was originally provided with double track throughout.ldquoAn electric train service from Haddington to Edinburgh would provide the speed and capacity which road transport ndash car or bus ndash cannot match. Frequency should be half-hourly.Councillor Tom Trotter, who represents Haddington, backed the station bid.He said: ldquoIt is a good idea, especially with the town expanding as it is.ldquoIt would be a tremendous asset to have.However, the councillor felt it was more likely the station would have to find a new site, such as Alderston, to the north of the town.He added: ldquoIn the short-term it is unrealistic, but hopefully in the longer term things can be put in place to make it a realistic possibility.ldquoIt is a great idea and Irsquom sure it would get support from all the local ward councillors, but where it would go and how much it would cost are questions.

title: preview-prestonpans-gala-2019
story: This year is the th anniversary of Prestonpans Childrenrsquos Gala.On gala day itself, the festivities kick off with the crowning ceremony at am at Prestonpans Community Centre.There is then a fancy-dress competition at Middleshot Square at noon before the parade heads off through the town.From Middleshot Square, it heads along Hawthorn Road and down West Loan to the war memorial, then along High Street before turning up Redburn Road, then along North Grange Avenue, where it ends at Mary Murray Park, behind the community centre.The park hosts the gala dayrsquos family fun, which includes a funfair with a host of rides, as well as old favourites such as hook the duck.There is also a vintage fire engine on display, as well as an American police car, motorbike displays, ponies, birds of prey, beat the goalie, Zorbs, safe archery, NERF guns, crazy golf, a tombola and a gala raffle, not to mention ice cream vans, tea and coffee, Mr Donut Man, crepes, waffles, hot dogs, nachos, a burger van, La Favorita pizzas, stalls selling gts, sweets and cake.Gala day marks the beginning, not the end of Prestonpansrsquo week of fun and activities.Events are as follows:Saturday, June Monday, June Tuesday, June Wednesday, June Thursday, June Friday, June

title: bid-to-turn-former-rbs-in-north-berwick-into-a-house
story: The townrsquos Royal Bank of Scotlandclosed in June last year. Since then, the building on Westgate has sat empty.But now Mr and Mrs Nigel Sharp are keen to transform the site, with plans to demolish the former bank hall and create a new house with office space. title: thousands-of-scottish-people-living-miserable-lives-on-the-hard-edge-study-says
story: Lead author of the Hard Edges Scotland study, Professor Suzanne Fitzpatrick, said the lives of many Scots are characterised by stress, misery, violence and trauma.Research carried out at Heriot-Watt University, found that almost , adults in Scotland experience at least one form of extreme disadvantage.Professor Fitzpatrick, director of the universityrsquos Institute for Social Policy, Housing and Equalities Research said: ldquoMany of the people directly affected are living miserable and stressful lives, constantly in lsquosurvival modersquo, because violence, trauma and threats play such a pervasive role in their everyday experiences.ldquoHaving no physical or psychological lsquosafe spacersquo takes a terrible toll on peoplersquos well-being and quality of le and addressing this distressing reality must be core to policy and service responses.When additional disadvantages such as mental ill-health and domestic violence are considered, the numbers affected more than double to nearly , people each year, researchers say. The study examines the challenges facing charities and the public sector, and says while many people face multiple problems, services are often set up to address single issues.It also warns that prisons and the courts are picking up the pieces after people in need of help are let down by other services. Rsearchers found numerous examples of people using the criminal justice service as a ldquosafety net and committing offences or seeking prison sentences to gain access to support and ldquosafe places.The report was commissioned by Lankelly Chase and The Robertson Trust. lice Evans, deputy chief executive of Lankelly Chase, said: ldquoThese findings tell the story of le as it is now for people facing extreme disadvantage across Scotland. Hard Edges Scotland asks us all to question the role wersquore playing in allowing this to continue. Te response required is bigger than any one inidual or organisation..Lankelly Chase is making pound, available to communities and organisations across Scotland to encourage new conversations about severe and multiple disadvantage and is offering grants of up to pound, from that fund to facilitate new discussions.The report looked at three ldquocore forms of severe and multiple disadvantage ndash homelessness, offending and substance dependency. Researchers found that , people experience at least one, , two and , adults experience all three.A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoWersquore taking action to address the underlying causes such as tackling poverty, delivering fair wages, supporting families, and improving the provision of alcohol and drug treatment services.

title: irn-bru-and-fish-and-chips-jeremy-hunt-bids-to-win-over-scottish-tories
story: Jeremy Hunt, who is battling Boris Johnson for the keys to Number , wants Scottish Tory members to know the Union is safe in his hands ndash and that he will support it, to use his words, with every drop of blood in his veins.The Foreign Secretary spent part of his childhood in Scotland and was using this campaign visit to pop in on his -year-old great-aunt Betty, who lives just outside Aberdeen.:Jeremy Hunt: Preserving the Union comes before BrexitIt was a trip aimed at burnishing Mr Hunts Scottish credentials, and the timing was impeccable.His visit to Peterhead came as a poll for the Sunday Times showed support for independence would climb to  per centBoris Johnson becomes Prime Minister. North of the Border, he is less popular than Nigel Farage.For many Scottish Tories, it is a chilling glimpse of the future. They fear Mr Johnson will spell disaster for their party and for the future of the UK.Its no wonder Mr Hunt looked cheerful as he arrived at Peterhead Port Authority at :pm, dressed casually in jeans, black trainers and an open-necked shirt.Greeted by local fisherman and industry representatives, he promptly disappeared into a room to discuss the impact of Brexit, before reemerging for photos and broadcast interviews onboard a moored trawler.At :pm, a van from Peterheads Mintlaw Chipper arrived bearing several bags of fish and chips. In a classy move other political campaigns could learn from, Mr Hunts press team had ensured there was enough for the gathered journalists.Inside the Port Authority building, the Foreign Secretary took questions from the press for just over ten minutes, cracking open a can of Irn-Bru as he did so.But did he actually like Scotlands other national drink ldquoIt is a new experience, and itrsquos very pleasant," he said, sounding slightly unconvincing.Elsewhere, he dodged questions about Mr Johnsons character following the revelation police were called to the home he shares with his partner, Carrie Symonds, after the couple apparently had a loud row.Instead, Mr Hunt repeatedly steered his answers back to his preferred talking point: Mr Johnsons failure to debate him on live TV before Tory members receive their postal ballots. Thats the thing most people want to hear about, he insisted.:Nicola Sturgeon: Boris Johnson as PM would be lsquodisastrousrsquo for ToriesAsked why the public should trust either of the Tory leadership frontrunners on Brexit, Mr Hunt said: "Im not saying its going to be easy. Im very clear this is a challenging thing to deliver.ldquoIrsquom also clear thatthe only way to leave the EU was with a no-deal Brexit, with a heavy heart, thatrsquos what Irsquod do.ldquoBut people have to make a judgement as to who EU leaders are more likely to engage with, more likely to negotiate with, more likely to trust.ldquoThey want to resolve this too. I think they will listen to what a new Prime Minister says and people have to judge who is the more likely person to resolve this crisis.He might not want to make his attacks personal, but he is nevertheless attempting to fuel a key question in the minds of Tory members. Who do they trust more with the countrys future Later, Mr Hunt travelled to Aberdeen, where he strolled along the esplanade and was photographed chatting to voters.Among them were Biddy Henderson, , and her daughter Jody, , who run the Country Quines Kitchen food van, looking out over the windswept beach.Mr Hunt was snapped chatting happily to the pair, but what did they really make of him "Theres none of them any better than the other," came Biddys withering assessment. "They really have no idea about the real world."Elsewhere, the feedback was more positive. Helen Wu, , hailed Mr Hunt for making the effort to travel to Aberdeen and said he would secure her support over Mr Johnson.Another local, Mandy Leslie, dismissed Mr Johnson as "Boris the buffoon".Mr Hunts great-aunt Betty ndash a lelong Conservative whose grandchildren work in the oil and gas industry ndash insisted she was proud of her great nephew, adding: "Hes a great listener, he always wants to hear your opinions."I think he would be a great Prime Minister because of his experience of running the Olympics, the NHS and as Foreign Secretary."He might have his familys backing, but Mr Hunt has a long way to gohe is to secure the keys to Number . With the winner announced in the week of July , Mr Johnsons lead looks untouchable. But a month is a long time in politics. Best stock up on the Irn-Bru.
